questions.q: The topology that consists of a central hub or switch, through which all of the data passes, along with all of the peripheral nodes connected to that central node is...
questions.explanation: Star topology uses a central controller (hub or switch) to connect all nodes.

questions.q: A campus network that is reside in an area around 800 meters, is more likely to be...
questions.explanation: A Local Area Network (LAN) typically covers a single building or a campus area up to a few kilometers.

questions.q: A data has been encapsulated with three separate headers and one trailer. What is the name for this PDU?
questions.explanation: A Frame (Data Link Layer) is the only PDU that typically includes both a header and a trailer (e.g., Ethernet trailer/FCS).

questions.q: The Link Layer of the TCP/IP Model is equivalent to which layer in the OSI Model?
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP Link Layer covers both the Physical and Data Link layers of the OSI model.

questions.q: The Layer that provides a node-to-node connectivity in the OSI model is...
questions.explanation: Data Link Layer (Layer 2) handles node-to-node delivery within the same local network.

questions.q: The Layer that provides a host-to-host connectivity in the OSI Model is...
questions.explanation: The Transport Layer (Layer 4) provides end-to-end (host-to-host) communication services.

questions.q: The Layer that is responsible for establishing, managing, terminating connections is....
questions.explanation: Layer 5 (Session Layer) manages the dialogue between computers.

questions.q: Sending data to a specific group of subscribed devices is....
questions.explanation: Multicast sends a single message to a specific group of interested recipients.

questions.q: A host in one network sends a message to all hosts in another network.
questions.explanation: Direct Broadcast is directed to all hosts on a specific remote network.

questions.q: Radio broadcast is a transmission example of....
questions.explanation: Simplex is one-way communication only.

questions.q: Walkie-Talkie broadcast is a transmission example of...
questions.explanation: Half-Duplex allows two-way communication but only one party can send at a time.

questions.q: Television broadcast is a transmission example of....
questions.explanation: Standard TV broadcasting is one-way (Simplex).

questions.q: In the straight through 568A UTP cable, the color of pin 7 wire is....
questions.explanation: In both T568A and T568B, Pin 7 is White/Brown and Pin 8 is Brown.

questions.q: In the straight through 568B UTP cable, the color of pin 2 wire is....
questions.explanation: In T568B, Pin 1 is White/Orange and Pin 2 is Orange.

questions.q: Which of the following addresses is considered a Private Address?
questions.explanation: Class B private range is 172.16.0.0 to 172.31.255.255.

questions.q: Which of the following addresses is considered a Public Address?
questions.explanation: 172.32.30.10 falls outside the private range.

questions.q: In class A IP Addresses, which Octet(s) contain the Network portion of the address?
questions.explanation: Class A uses the first octet for the Network ID (N.H.H.H).

questions.q: In class B IP Addresses, which Octet(s) contain the Host portion of the address?
questions.explanation: Class B uses the first two octets for Network and the last two (3rd and 4th) for the Host portion.

questions.q: In class C IP Addresses, what is the available number of hosts per network?
questions.explanation: 2^8 - 2 = 254 usable hosts.

questions.q: In class B IP Addresses, what is the available number of networks?
questions.explanation: Class B uses 14 bits for the network identification (2^14 = 16,384).

questions.q: IPv6 addresses are 256-bit numbers.
questions.explanation: IPv6 addresses are 128-bit numbers.

questions.q: The Subnet Mask corresponding to a CIDR of /26 is 255.255.192.0
questions.explanation: /26 corresponds to 255.255.255.192.

questions.q: The last valid host on the network 172.21.92.0 with subnet mask 255.255.254.0 is 172.21.93.254
questions.explanation: Mask /23 means the network range is 172.21.92.0 - 172.21.93.255. Last host is 93.254.

questions.q: The subnet mask you would use for the Network ID 172.23.0.0, such that you can get 1330 subnets and 20 hosts per subnet is 255.255.255.224
questions.explanation: A /27 mask (255.255.255.224) provides 32 - 5 = 27 bits for network. From a Class B /16, that's 11 bits for subnets (2^11 = 2048) and 5 bits for hosts (2^5 - 2 = 30). This fits the requirement.

questions.q: The corresponding CIDR for the subnet mask of 255.255.128.0 is /17
The First valid host for the network that the host IP address 172.27.131.208/22 is a part of is 172.27.128.10
questions.explanation: The network is 172.27.128.0. The first valid host is 172.27.128.1.

questions.q: The Network Layer is responsible for managing IP addresses.
questions.explanation: IP Addressing and routing occur at Layer 3 (Network Layer).

questions.q: Full mesh topology is considered a very expensive topology.
questions.explanation: It requires (n*(n-1))/2 connections, making it costly and complex.

questions.q: In Limited Broadcast the data reaches from a source to all the host in a same network.
questions.explanation: Limited Broadcast (255.255.255.255) is restricted to the local network segment.

questions.q: Mobile phone call is an example of full-duplex communication.
questions.explanation: Both parties can talk and hear at the same time.

questions.q: Class E IP addresses is reserved for multicast addressing.
questions.explanation: Class D is for Multicast; Class E is reserved for experimental use.

questions.q: Video Conferencing is an example of half-duplex communication.
questions.explanation: Modern Video Conferencing is full-duplex.

questions.q: T568A and T568B are the same but reversing the positions of the orange and blue pairs
questions.explanation: The swap occurs between the Orange and Green pairs.

questions.q: Data in Transport Layer is called Segment.
questions.explanation: Layer 4 PDUs are called Segments (TCP) or Datagrams (UDP).

questions.q: By dividing the network IP address 192.168.1.0 into 7 subnets, the third subnet will have a Network ID 192.168.1.128
questions.explanation: To get 7 subnets, you borrow 3 bits (8 subnets). Increments of 32. Net 0: .0, Net 1: .32, Net 2: .64. .128 would be the 5th subnet (Net 4).

questions.q: Coaxial cables can transmit data much faster than twisted pair cables.
questions.explanation: Historically/Technically, coaxial has higher bandwidth potential than early twisted pair, though modern Cat6/7 has closed the gap.

questions.q: The cable that used as a medium for carrying light waves is fiber optic cable.
questions.explanation: Correct, fiber optics use light pulses.

questions.q: Auto-MDIX is a feature that allows network devices to automatically transform all cables to straight-through.
questions.explanation: It doesn't physically change the cable; it detects the required cable type and configures the interface internally to match.

questions.q: The IP address 127.10.20.30 indicates a loopback address.
questions.explanation: The entire 127.0.0.0/8 range is reserved for loopback.

questions.q: Session establishment is handled by layer 5 in the OSI model.
questions.explanation: Correct, that is the primary function of the Session Layer.

questions.q: Given this Network ID 172.16.0.0/16, create 65 subnetworks and each subnet has to be able to hold 150 valid hosts. (Enumerate all possible scenarios)
options: To get 65 subnets, we need 7 bits (2^7=128 subnets). To get 150 hosts, we need 8 bits (2^8-2=254 hosts). Total bits needed = 16 (original) + 7 (subnet) = /23. Since 23 + 8 = 31, we have enough bits in the IPv4 address. Scenario: Use mask 255.255.254.0 (/23). This provides 128 possible subnets, each supporting up to 510 hosts, which exceeds the required 65 subnets and 150 hosts.
questions.explanation: This requires moving from a /16 to at least a /23 to satisfy both the subnet count and host count requirements.
